## <span style="font-size:70%">Study Background</span> {.smaller}

::: columns
::: {.column width="100%"}
**What is CAR-T cell therapy?**

- CAR-T cell therapy: form of immunotherapy that leverages a patient’s immune system to fight cancer
- Researchers genetically engineer a patient’s T cells to express receptors (chimeric antigen receptors - CARs) that recognize specific antigens on cancer cells
- Genetically re-engineered T-cells (CAR-T cells) are  re-infused into the patient where the T cells seek out and destroy tumor cells
- Often used to treat: hematologic cancers like acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL)

:::

::: {.column width="0%"}
::: incremental




:::
:::
<span style="font-size:60%">Chohan KL, et al. (2023). Curr Hematol Malig Rep.</span>
:::
::: footer
:::


## <span style="font-size:70%">Study Background</span> {.smaller}

::: columns
::: {.column width="100%"}
**How are adverse events measured?** 

- CAR-T therapy is a form of immunotherapy that stimulates the immune system to attack cancer that can have a range of side effects:
- Grades 1–5 refer to the severity of adverse events or toxicities:
- **Grade 1 (Mild)**: minimal symptoms; does not require intervention (i.e.: mild rash)
- **Grade 2 (Moderate)**: symptoms are more noticeable and may require minimal medical intervention (moderate nausea)

:::

::: {.column width="0%"}
::: incremental




:::
:::

:::
::: footer
:::

## <span style="font-size:70%">Study Background</span> {.smaller}

::: columns
::: {.column width="100%"}
**How are adverse events measured?**

- **Grade 3 (Severe)**: medically significant and requires intervention, possibly hospitalization (i.e.: severe organ dysfunction)
- **Grade 4 (Life-Threatening)**: urgent, life-threatening consequences; requires immediate medical intervention (i.e.: respiratory failure)
- **Grade 5 (Death)**: toxicity results in patient death

:::

::: {.column width="0%"}
::: incremental




:::
:::

:::
::: footer

## Define the insight first


::: columns
::: {.column .small}

*Task*: Define central message that drives the design of the plot

After evaluating your patient data show:

Most patients experience only Grade 1–2 toxicities as shown by ordering of lines in plot

:::
::: column

```{r}
#| fig-width: 8
#| fig-height: 9

# Install/Load Libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)

# Simulate data
toxicity_data <- data.frame(
  Toxicity = factor(paste("Grade", 1:5), levels = paste("Grade", 1:5)),
  CRS_Count = c(30, 25, 10, 5, 2),
  Neuro_Count = c(28, 22, 12, 4, 1)
)

# Summarize total events
toxicity_data <- toxicity_data %>%
  mutate(Total_Count = CRS_Count + Neuro_Count)

# Generate grey lollipop plot
ggplot(toxicity_data, aes(x = Toxicity, y = Total_Count)) +
  geom_segment(aes(xend = Toxicity, y = 0, yend = Total_Count), size = 1, color = "grey50") +
  geom_point(size = 4, color = "grey30") +
  labs(
    title = "CAR-T Therapy Toxicity Grades",
    subtitle = "Most patients experience only Grade 1–2 toxicities",
    x = "Toxicity Grade",
    y = "Number of Patients"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 15) +
  theme(
    panel.grid = element_blank(),
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold")
  )



```

## Hierarchy of Importance

::: columns
::: {.column .small}

*Task*: Key categories are visually prioritized

After evaluating your patient data show:

  - The intervention you developed is safe for most of the patients in your study
  - Most patients experience only Grade 1–2 toxicities
  - Grades 1–2 are visually emphasized with coral color, signaling they are the most important part of the story
  - Grades 3–5 are muted grey, still visible for context but clearly secondary

:::
::: column

```{r}
#| fig-width: 8
#| fig-height: 9

#Install Load/Libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)

# Simulate data
toxicity_data <- data.frame(
  Toxicity = factor(paste("Grade", 1:5), levels = paste("Grade", 1:5)),
  CRS_Count = c(30, 25, 10, 5, 2),
  Neuro_Count = c(28, 22, 12, 4, 1)
)

# Summarize total events for simplicity
toxicity_data <- toxicity_data %>%
  mutate(Total_Count = CRS_Count + Neuro_Count,
         Highlight = ifelse(Toxicity %in% c("Grade 1", "Grade 2"), "Highlight", "Other"))

# Generate plot
ggplot(toxicity_data, aes(x = Toxicity, y = Total_Count, color = Highlight)) +
  geom_segment(aes(xend = Toxicity, y = 0, yend = Total_Count), size = 1) +
  geom_point(size = 4) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("Highlight" = "coral", "Other" = "grey70")) +
  labs(
    title = "CAR-T Therapy Toxicity Grades",
    subtitle = "Most patients experience only Grade 1–2 toxicities",
    x = "Toxicity Grade",
    y = "Number of Patients"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 15) +
  theme(
    panel.grid = element_blank(),
    legend.position = "none",
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold")
  )
```

## Logical ordering

::: columns
::: {.column .small}

Categories flow in a way that reinforces the central point

**X-axis ordering**: Grades 1–5 are sequential, reflecting the natural progression of toxicity severity

**Y-axis**: Total count of patients experiencing each grade (CRS + Neurotoxicity) communicates magnitude clearly

**Lollipop design**: Length of the bar (frequency) draws attention to the point of interest

:::
::: column

```{r}
#| fig-width: 8
#| fig-height: 9

#Install Load/Libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)

# Simulate data
toxicity_data <- data.frame(
  Toxicity = factor(paste("Grade", 1:5), levels = paste("Grade", 1:5)),
  CRS_Count = c(30, 25, 10, 5, 2),
  Neuro_Count = c(28, 22, 12, 4, 1)
)

# Summarize total events and create highlight for Grades 1–2
toxicity_data <- toxicity_data %>%
  mutate(Total_Count = CRS_Count + Neuro_Count,
         Highlight = ifelse(Toxicity %in% c("Grade 1", "Grade 2"), "Highlight", "Other"))

# Generate plot
ggplot(toxicity_data, aes(x = Toxicity, y = Total_Count, color = Highlight)) +
  geom_segment(aes(xend = Toxicity, y = 0, yend = Total_Count), size = 1) +
  geom_point(size = 4) +
  geom_text(aes(label = Total_Count), vjust = -0.5, size = 5) +  # Optional labels
  scale_color_manual(values = c("Highlight" = "coral", "Other" = "grey70")) +
  labs(
    title = "CAR-T Therapy Toxicity Grades",
    subtitle = "Most patients experience only Grade 1–2 toxicities",
    x = "Toxicity Grade",
    y = "Number of Patients"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 15) +
  theme(
    panel.grid = element_blank(),  # minimal gridlines
    legend.position = "none",      # no legend clutter
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold")
  )

```

## Visual Guidance


::: columns
::: {.column .small}

**Direct the viewer’s attention to the most important category while providing context for comparison**

**Highlighting key grades**: Immediately draws the eye to Grades 1–2

**Minimal gridlines and no legend clutter**: Reduces distractions and ensures the story is read instantly

**Labels (optional)** could reinforce counts if necessary

:::
::: column

```{r}
#| fig-width: 8
#| fig-height: 9

# Install/Load Libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)

# Simulate data
toxicity_data <- data.frame(
  Toxicity = factor(paste("Grade", 1:5), levels = paste("Grade", 1:5)),
  CRS_Count = c(30, 25, 10, 5, 2),
  Neuro_Count = c(28, 22, 12, 4, 1)
)

# Summarize total events and flag Grades 1–2 for highlighting
toxicity_data <- toxicity_data %>%
  mutate(
    Total_Count = CRS_Count + Neuro_Count,
    Highlight = ifelse(Toxicity %in% c("Grade 1", "Grade 2"), "Highlight", "Other")
  )

# Generate minimalist, focus-driven plot
ggplot(toxicity_data, aes(x = Toxicity, y = Total_Count)) +
  # Base segments for all grades (light gray for context)
  geom_segment(aes(xend = Toxicity, y = 0, yend = Total_Count),
               color = "grey80", size = 1) +
  
  # Highlighted segments and points for Grades 1–2
  geom_segment(
    data = filter(toxicity_data, Highlight == "Highlight"),
    aes(xend = Toxicity, y = 0, yend = Total_Count),
    color = "coral", size = 1.5
  ) +
  geom_point(
    data = filter(toxicity_data, Highlight == "Highlight"),
    aes(y = Total_Count),
    color = "coral", size = 5
  ) +
  geom_point(
    data = filter(toxicity_data, Highlight == "Other"),
    aes(y = Total_Count),
    color = "grey70", size = 4
  ) +
  
  # Optional labels reinforcing counts
  geom_text(
    aes(label = Total_Count),
    vjust = -0.6,
    size = 5,
    color = "black"
  ) +
  
  # Titles and labels
  labs(
    title = "CAR-T Therapy Toxicity Grades",
    subtitle = "Grades 1–2 dominate patient experiences; higher grades are rare",
    x = "Toxicity Grade",
    y = "Number of Patients"
  ) +
  
  # Minimalist theme: clean grid, no legend, clear text hierarchy
  theme_minimal(base_size = 15) +
  theme(
    panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    axis.ticks = element_blank(),
    legend.position = "none",
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(margin = margin(b = 10))
  )

```

## <span style="font-size:80%">Summary</span> {.smaller}

::: columns
::: {.column width="0%"}

:::

::: {.column width="90%"}


When developing a single-message figure:

Visual that provides clarity of interpretation;
  
  - Viewer instantly understands the main insight

Make the Intended Insight Immediately Clear:

  - Before plotting, ask: “What is the single insight I want my audience to take away?”

  - The entire visual structure — the arrangement of categories, ordering, and supporting elements — should make this insight obvious at first glance
